Pour ce faire, Blandine Afiavi Sèonmian vend des condiments et divers produits à son domicile depuis quinze ans. Blandine Afiavi Sèonmian s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son fonds de roulement, Blandine Afiavi Sèonmian s’associe aux autres membres de son groupe pour solliciter un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
This group is made up of three people who live in the same neighborhood. The group's representative is the woman raising her hand in the photograph. Her name is Blandine Afiavi Sèonmian, she's 34 years old, and married to one Eric. They have three children together, whom they have to support. All three attend school. 

Blandine Afiavi Sèonmian never went to school. She lives with her husband and children. She covers the various expenses of their household with her husband. To do so, she's been selling condiments and various products at her home for fifteen years. She gets her supplies in a market in Benin.

Eager to bolster her working capital, Blandine Afiavi Sèonmian, together with the other members of the group, is seeking a first loan from Kiva's partner, ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy condiments and various products

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is single with four children and three of her children go to school. She has no additional family members. She operates a stall of fruits and vegetables at the market. She sells her goods to all kinds of people on a retail basis. She has been in the business for 3 years. She works seven days a week.   She gets additional income from cleaning city roads. She has applied for a loan of Uganda Shillings 500,000 from MCDTSACCO to buy fish fresh beans, tomatoes, onions, Irish potatoes and passion fruit. Her major business challenge is the perishability and seasonality of her fruits.  She is aspiring to start growing vegetables so as to increase her profits and also to become a wholesaler.  She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expense includes school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more fish, fresh beans, tomatoes, onions, Irish potatoes and passion fruit.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose has a boutique business in Naivasha town and has been in the business for 6 years. She is 39 years old and married to Vitalis and together they are blessed with two children who are in school.

This is her third loan term from KADET LTD and she plans to use the amount to buy more stocks of clothes for sale and use the generated income to pay school fees for her children.
 
In the near future, she hopes to own the biggest boutique in Naivasha.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha cooks food for sale at the market and sells to town dwellers and passersby. She cites food left-over’s leading to losses hence it is her major challenge in the business. She dreams of establishing a café business in the future.  In addition she sells coconuts to supplement her income.

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants  to purchase food ingredients such as beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for food preparation. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase food ingredients such as beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for food preparation.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en: Robinah  is single with seven children and three of her children go to school. She has one additional family member (a sister). She sells fish at the market. She sells her goods to all kinds of people on a retail basis. She has been in this business for 4 years. She works six days a week. She has applied for a loan of Uganda Shillings 500,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more baskets of fresh fish. Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality of her products. She hopes to educate her children up to the university level.  She resides in her own house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expense includes school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more  baskets of fresh fish.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is married with four children and two of her children go to school. She has no additional family members. She operates a beauty salon from  a shop on a retail basis. She has been in the business for 4 years. She works seven days a week. She also gets additional income from selling second hand clothes. She has applied for a loan of Uganda Shillings 500,000 from MCDTSACCO to buy hair treatments, weaves, relaxers and braids. Her major business challenges include electricity which hinders her business operations. She is aspiring of getting a fully stocked beauty salon and also,  permanent business premises.  She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expense includes school fees, rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of hair treatments, weaves, relaxers and braids.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is married with three children, one of whom goes to school. She has no additional family members. She sells secondhand clothes at the market on a retail basis. She has been in business for many years. She works six days a week. She earns additional income from operating a grocery shop. She has applied for a loan of UGX 500,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy bales of secondhand clothes and sugar, rice and soap for her grocery store. Her major business challenges include seasonality (rainy season), which hinders her movements and transportation. She aspires to find a permanent residence.  She resides in a rented house where the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food for the family.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, all who are currently in school. For the past five years, Hasan has been working hard to manage his boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Hasan has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes to sell, and will help Hasan generate greater profits, expand his business, and add additional types of clothes. Hasan hopes that in the future he will be able to produce quality products. 

Hasan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hasan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.
